thread.title: Lincoln-Way gets bids to sell land
thread.title_full: Lincoln-Way gets bids to sell land

author: Susan DeMar Lafferty
title: Lincoln-Way gets bids to sell land
text:
(Gregory Pratt) 
"This is a gem for Manhattan," she said, adding that the site could be developed as a future sports complex. 
"This is definitely a good thing for Manhattan. You won't find this again," Popp said of the open space. 
Spiess Farms was the successful bidder for the 100 acres at 16462 W. Manhattan Road, also in Manhattan, with an offer of $1,250,000. The district sought a minimum price of $1.2 million. 
Tingley said he anticipates the sales of the Manhattan properties to go quickly, because no special zoning is required for the new owners. 
The Tinley Park property has been under contract several times. The district initially planned to build its Lincoln-Way North High School on this busy commercial intersection, and when parents objected the school was moved to 199th and Harlem. 
North was closed in June 2016 due to the district's financial woes and declining enrollment. 
In other matters during Thursday board meeting: 
â€¢Action on student registration fees for the 2017-18 school year were tabled until the March meeting, but Tingley recommended a $10 increase in the $60 technology fee for freshmen, sophomores and juniors to cover the cost of the SAT test now required by the state. No other fee increases were recommended, but in comparing Lincoln-Way to seven other high school districts, it was noted that many charge a fee to participate in sports.
